title: Lesson 2: Sound as a Longitudinal Wave - Compressions and Rarefactions
content:
Lesson 2: Sound as a Longitudinal Wave

The Secret "Squeeze and Stretch" Dance of Sound

We know a vibrating object pushes air particles, but how does this 'push' travel? What if I told you sound moves through the air like a Slinky, doing a special kind of "forward-and-back" dance?

Let's uncover this special dance and learn the scientific words for the "squeeze" and "stretch" parts of a sound wave.

Sound's Special Dance: The Longitudinal Wave

A wave is simply a disturbance that transfers energy from one place to another. There are two main types of waves, and sound belongs to a special category.

The "Up-and-Down" Wave (Transverse)

Think of a wave on a rope. The wave travels forward, but the rope itself moves up and down. This is a transverse wave, where particle motion is perpendicular (at 90¬∞) to the wave's direction. Light is a transverse wave.

The "Push-and-Pull" Wave (Longitudinal)

Sound is different. The air particles move back and forth, in the same direction as the wave travels. This is a longitudinal wave, where particle motion is parallel to the wave's direction.

The Building Blocks: Compressions & Rarefactions

A longitudinal sound wave is made of a repeating pattern of two types of regions:

How a Vibrating Fork Creates a Sound Wave

A sound wave is a series of compressions (C) and rarefactions (R) propagating through a medium.

Compressions (C) - The "Squeeze"

This is a region where the particles of the medium are crowded or bunched together.

  • Created when the source moves forward.
  • Region of high particle density.
  • Region of high pressure.

Rarefactions (R) - The "Stretch"

This is a region where the particles of the medium are spread apart.

  • Created when the source moves backward.
  • Region of low particle density.
  • Region of low pressure.

Lesson 2 in a Nutshell

1. Sound is a Longitudinal Wave.

This means the particles of the medium vibrate parallel (in the same direction) to the direction of wave travel.

2. It is made of Compressions and Rarefactions.

Compression (C) = High pressure/density region.
Rarefaction (R) = Low pressure/density region.
questions:
Lesson 2: Questions & Answers

1. In one sentence, why is a sound wave called a longitudinal wave?

A sound wave is called a longitudinal wave because the particles of the medium vibrate parallel to the direction in which the sound energy is traveling.

2. A wave is created by wiggling a rope up and down. Is this wave the same type as a sound wave? Explain the key difference.

No, the wave on a rope is a transverse wave, which is different from a sound wave.

  1. Rope Wave (Transverse): The parts of the rope move perpendicularly (up and down) to the direction the wave is traveling (forward).
  2. Sound Wave (Longitudinal): The particles of air move parallel (back and forth) to the direction the wave is traveling.

The key difference is the direction of particle vibration relative to the direction of wave travel (perpendicular vs. parallel).

3. In the context of a sound wave, what is the difference between a compression and a rarefaction?

The main difference lies in the density and pressure of the particles in the medium.

Compression (C)

A region where particles are crowded together. It is a region of high density and high pressure.

Rarefaction (R)

A region where particles are spread apart. It is a region of low density and low pressure.

4. A vibrating speaker cone moves forward, then backward, then forward again. Match the motion to the region it creates in the air.

  1. Forward Motion: When the speaker cone moves forward, it pushes and "squeezes" the air particles in front of it. This creates a compression.
  2. Backward Motion: When the speaker cone moves backward, it leaves a space with fewer air particles. This creates a "stretched" area, which is a rarefaction.

5. Look at the diagram below representing a sound wave. Which letters (A, B, C, D) point to regions of rarefaction?

The letters pointing to regions of rarefaction are B and D.

  1. Step 1: Identify Compressions. Compressions are where the lines (representing particles) are crowded together. In the diagram, these are regions A and C.
  2. Step 2: Identify Rarefactions. Rarefactions are where the lines are spread far apart. In the diagram, these are regions B and D.

6. A sound wave is also called a mechanical wave. How do compressions and rarefactions help explain why it's a mechanical wave?

A mechanical wave is a wave that needs a medium (matter) to travel.

  1. Step 1: The Role of Particles. The very existence of compressions (crowded particles) and rarefactions (spread-out particles) proves that the wave depends on the particles of a medium.
  2. Step 2: The Need for a Medium. Without particles, you cannot have regions of high particle density (compressions) or low particle density (rarefactions).
  3. Step 3: Conclusion. Therefore, the fact that a sound wave consists of compressions and rarefactions confirms it is a mechanical wave that requires a physical medium for its propagation.

7. If you could see a sound wave in the air, would it look more like a wave on a rope or a wave on a Slinky? Explain your choice.

It would look more like a wave on a Slinky.

  • A wave on a rope is transverse (up-and-down motion).
  • A wave on a Slinky (when pushed) is longitudinal (back-and-forth motion), creating areas where the coils are bunched up (compressions) and areas where they are spread out (rarefactions).
  • Since a sound wave in air is a longitudinal wave made of compressions and rarefactions, the Slinky is the correct visual model.

8. A friend says, "A compression is just a bunch of air that travels from the speaker to your ear." Is this statement correct? Clarify any misunderstanding.

The statement is not correct. It has a common misunderstanding.

  1. The Misunderstanding: The idea that the air particles themselves travel across the room.
  2. The Clarification: The compression is a region of high pressure, not a fixed group of particles. The individual particles only vibrate back and forth around their fixed positions. They pass the energy to their neighbours, which causes the *region* of compression to move forward, like a wave in a stadium crowd. The particles stay, but the wave travels.

9. What is pressure, and how is it related to the density of particles in a sound wave?

Pressure is related to how often particles collide with each other and their container. The relationship is direct:

  • High Density (Compression): When particles are crowded together (high density), they collide more frequently. This results in high pressure.
  • Low Density (Rarefaction): When particles are spread far apart (low density), they collide less frequently. This results in low pressure.

So, a sound wave is essentially a traveling wave of pressure changes.

exercises:
Lesson 2: Exercises

1. Analogy Check: Which Wave is Which?

Below are two types of waves seen in a stadium. Which one is like a sound wave (longitudinal) and which one is like a light wave (transverse)? Explain why.

A: The "Mexican Wave"

People stand up and sit down in sequence. The wave moves around the stadium.

B: A "Push" Wave

People in a line push the person in front, creating a "bunch-up" that travels.

  • A (The "Mexican Wave") is like a light wave (transverse).
    Reason: The people (particles) move up and down, which is perpendicular to the direction the wave travels around the stadium.
  • B (The "Push" Wave) is like a sound wave (longitudinal).
    Reason: The people (particles) move back and forth in the same direction that the "bunch-up" (compression) travels along the line. This parallel motion is the key characteristic of a longitudinal wave.

3. Correct the False Statements

The following statements are incorrect. Rewrite each one to make it true.

  • A) In a longitudinal wave, particles vibrate perpendicularly to the wave's direction.
  • B) A sound wave is made of crests and troughs.
  • C) The pressure in a rarefaction is higher than the surrounding air pressure.

Corrected Statements:

  • A) In a longitudinal wave, particles vibrate parallel to the wave's direction.
  • B) A sound wave is made of compressions and rarefactions. (Crests and troughs are characteristic of transverse waves).
  • C) The pressure in a rarefaction is lower than the surrounding air pressure.

4. Drawing Challenge

Imagine a piston in a tube full of air particles. Draw two simple diagrams:

  1. The piston after it has just moved forward.

Label the compression or rarefaction created in each case.

5. Thought Experiment: Particle Journey

A tiny dust particle is floating in the air. A loud, continuous hum from a large machine starts, and the sound wave passes over the dust particle. Describe the motion of the dust particle. Does it travel across the room with the sound?

Description of Motion:

The dust particle will not travel across the room. Instead, it will simply oscillate or vibrate back and forth around its original fixed position.

As each compression passes, the dust particle is pushed forward slightly. As each rarefaction passes, it is pulled backward. Since the sound is continuous, the dust particle will continuously vibrate back and forth, but it will not have any significant overall movement from its starting point. It only helps to pass the energy of the sound wave along.

6. Categorize the Term

Which of the following terms describes the type of wave sound is?

  • Compression
  • Longitudinal
  • Rarefaction
  • Mechanical

Explain your choice, and also explain what the term "Mechanical" describes.

Longitudinal is the term that describes the type of wave sound is, based on the direction of particle vibration.

  • Longitudinal: This describes *how* the particles move (parallel to the wave's direction).
  • Mechanical: This describes *what* the wave needs to travel (a physical medium). Sound is also a mechanical wave. While correct, "longitudinal" more specifically describes its *type* of motion.
  • Compression & Rarefaction: These are the *parts* of a longitudinal wave, not the type of wave itself.
intros:
Lesson 2: Sound as a Longitudinal Wave

We know sound travels, but HOW does it travel? Discover the secret "squeeze and stretch" motion that defines every sound wave.

Intro 1: The Slinky Wave

Have you ever played with a Slinky? What if a simple push on this toy could perfectly explain how sound travels?

When you push a Slinky, you create a "bunch-up" of coils that travels down its length. This is exactly how sound travels through the air! A vibrating source (like a speaker) pushes the air particles, creating a bunched-up, high-pressure area called a compression. When the source pulls back, it creates a stretched-out, low-pressure area called a rarefaction.

The key thing to notice is that the Slinky coils (and the air particles) move back and forth in the *same direction* that the wave is traveling. This type of wave is called a longitudinal wave.

Sound's Secret Motion: A Forward-and-Back Wave of Compressions!

Intro 2: The Crowded Bus Analogy

Imagine pushing your way onto a crowded bus. How is that chaotic shuffle just like a sound wave?

A vibrating sound source is like someone trying to get onto an already full bus. It pushes the people (or air particles) right in front of it, causing them to get squeezed together. This squeezed, high-density area is a compression.

The squeezed people then bump into the people behind them, passing the "squeeze" along. The area behind the squeeze, where people have more space again, is a rarefaction. This wave of squeezing and stretching travels through the bus (the medium), but each person only shuffles a little bit. This is a perfect analogy for a longitudinal wave, where particles are displaced along the direction of the wave's travel.

Sound's Journey: A repeating pattern of getting squeezed and finding space!

Intro 3: The Two Wave Dances

If a wave on a rope does an "up-and-down" dance, what kind of dance does a sound wave do?

There are two main "dances" a wave can do. In a transverse wave (like a wave on a rope or a light wave), the particles dance up and down, *perpendicular* to the direction the wave is traveling.

But sound does a different dance. It's a longitudinal wave. Here, the air particles dance back and forth, *parallel* to the direction the sound is traveling. This back-and-forth dance creates the areas of squeeze (compressions) and stretch (rarefactions) that carry the sound to your ear.

Sound's Dance Move: A parallel shuffle, not a perpendicular jump!

Intro 4: The Invisible Pulses

You can't see sound, but if you could, it wouldn't look like a smooth wave. It would look like a series of invisible pulses. What are they?

Every sound wave is a traveling pattern of changing pressure. When a vibrating object moves forward, it shoves air particles together, creating a pulse of high pressure. This pulse is called a Compression.

When the object moves backward, it leaves behind a space for the air particles to spread out, creating a pulse of low pressure. This is a Rarefaction. Sound propagates by sending out this alternating sequence of high-pressure and low-pressure pulses through the medium, which our ears detect and interpret.

Sound's True Form: A traveling chain of high and low pressure pulses.

Intro 5: The Piston Push

How is a simple piston, like in an engine, a perfect model for how a sound wave is born?

Any vibrating object, like a tuning fork or a speaker cone, acts like a tiny piston. When it moves forward, it pushes on the air, compressing the particles together into a zone of high pressure. This zone is called a compression.

When the piston (or vibrating object) moves backward, it creates a space with fewer particles, a zone of low pressure. This is a rarefaction. As the object continues to vibrate, it sends out a continuous series of these compressions and rarefactions, which travel away as a longitudinal sound wave.

The Birth of a Sound Wave: A simple push and pull on the air.
summary:
Lesson 2: Summary

A quick revision guide on the nature of sound waves and their key components.

1. Sound is a Longitudinal Wave

Definition: A wave in which the particles of the medium vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation.

Key Characteristic: The direction of particle oscillation is the same as (or opposite to) the direction of energy transfer.

Contrast (Transverse Wave): In a transverse wave (e.g., light, wave on a rope), particles oscillate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation.

2. Components of a Sound Wave

A sound wave propagates as a series of alternating regions of high and low pressure/density.

Compression (C)

  • A region where particles are crowded or bunched together.
  • Corresponds to a region of high particle density.
  • Corresponds to a region of high pressure.

Rarefaction (R)

  • A region where particles are spread apart.
  • Corresponds to a region of low particle density.
  • Corresponds to a region of low pressure.
